question_german: In der Bildunterschrift wird erwähnt, dass die Grafik einen 'monotonen Anstieg der logarithmischen Wahrscheinlichkeit (θ) nach jeder Iteration des EM-Algorithmus' zeigt. Wie wird diese logarithmische Wahrscheinlichkeit im Paper berechnet?
question_english: The caption mentions that the graph shows a 'monotonous increase in log probability (θ) after each iteration of the EM algorithm'. How is this log probability calculated in the paper?
corrected_answer_german: Im Paper wird die Berechnung mithilfe des Forward-Backward-Algorithmus beschrieben. Dabei werden für jeden Zustand im Agendabaum Vorwärts- und Rückwärtswahrscheinlichkeiten berechnet. Diese Wahrscheinlichkeiten dienen zur Bestimmung der Übergangswahrscheinlichkeit zwischen Zuständen und anschließend zur Aktualisierung der Modellparameter, wodurch letztendlich die logarithmische Wahrscheinlichkeit der beobachteten Daten berechnet wird.
corrected_answer_english: The paper describes the calculation using the forward/backward algorithm. This involves calculating forward and backward probabilities for each state in the agenda tree. These probabilities are used to determine the probability of transitioning between states and then to update the model parameters, ultimately calculating the log probability of the observed data.
context:
Finally, the push transition model parameters are updated using

_Pˆ(zpush|zcond) =_ �

_{k,i,j�|SP A=zpush,SC=zcond}_ _[τ][k][(][i, j][)]_

_{k,i,j|SC=zcond}_ _[τ][t][(][i, j][)]_ (47)

where the summation subscripts indicate if the summary push action (SPA) zpush and summary condition (SC) _zcond were used to transition from i to j at step k._

question_german: Nennen Sie die Strategien, die in der Grafik dargestellt sind, und beschreiben Sie anhand des Kurvenverlaufs deren Effektivität im Verhältnis zum steigenden Aufwand der Annotation.
question_english: Name the strategies depicted in the graph and describe their effectiveness in relation to the increasing effort of annotation based on the course of the curves.
corrected_answer_german: Die Strategien sind 'confiance minimale', 'confiance minimale normalisée', 'proportion', 'random', 'information density' und 'entropie'. 'Proportion' (grün) ist am effektivsten und erreicht schnell eine hohe Präzision mit geringen Annotationskosten. 'Confiance minimale normalisée' (schwarz) schneidet ebenfalls gut ab und holt bei höheren Annotationskosten auf.  'Information density' (cyan) und 'confiance minimale' (rot) zeigen eine moderate Effektivität, während 'random' (blau) und 'entropie' (magenta) am wenigsten effektiv sind.
corrected_answer_english: The strategies are 'confiance minimale', 'confiance minimale normalisée', 'proportion', 'random', 'information density', and 'entropie'. 'Proportion' (green) is most effective, rapidly reaching high precision with low annotation cost. 'Confiance minimale normalisée' (black) also performs well, catching up at higher annotation costs.  'Information density' (cyan) and 'confiance minimale' (red) show moderate effectiveness, while 'random' (blue) and 'entropie' (magenta) are the least effective.

question_german: Der Text erwähnt, dass die Passagen 2 und 15 in allen Stilen bis auf einen konsistent sind. Welcher Stil ist in diesen Passagen unterschiedlich und was könnte dies laut Text bedeuten?
question_english: The text mentions that passages 2 and 15 are consistent in all styles but one. Which style is different in those passages, and what might this indicate, according to the text?
corrected_answer_german: 'Passagen 2 und 15 sind in allen Stilen außer umgangssprachlich konsistent (p < 0.01). Jeder Abschnitt zeigt Prufrock in einem anderen Geisteszustand: Im zweiten Abschnitt erzählt er eine bizarre Geschichte darüber, wie er einen alten Freund aus dem Krimkrieg fragt, ob eine Leiche, die er in seinem Garten gepflanzt hat, „angefangen hat zu sprießen“; in seinem zwölften Abschnitt berichtet er sachlich über eine Begegnung mit einem Kaufmann; in seinem fünfzehnten Abschnitt schimpft er in einem prophetischen Ton, der an eine andere Figur, den Höllenfeuerprediger, erinnert, was seiner üblichen Umgangssprache zu widersprechen scheint.'
corrected_answer_english: 'Passages 2 and 15 are consistent in all styles but colloquial (p < 0.01). Each passage finds Prufrock in a different mental state: in his second passage, he tells a bizarre story about asking an old friend from the Crimean War whether a corpse he had planted in his garden has “begun to sprout”; in his twelfth, he provides a entirely factual account of an encounter with a merchant; in his fifteenth, he rants in a prophetic tone reminiscent of another character, the Hellfire Preacher, which seems to counter his usual colloquialness.';Questions Requiring Additional Context;'As already noted, the character Crazy Prufrock is to some degree defined in terms of his stylistic variation (see Figure 6). His second (60-76), twelfth (207-214), and fifteenth (367-377) passages provide a representative sample of the stylistic range of this disturbed and inconsistent character. There are strong stylistic links between these passages, yet also clear differences. Passages 2 and 12 are almost identical in their values for abstract and colloquial values, but 12 has a much lower value for literary (p < 0.01). Passages 2 and 15 are consistent in all five styles except colloquial (p < 0.01). Each passage finds Prufrock in a different mental state: in his second passage, he tells a bizarre story about asking an old friend from the Crimean War whether a corpse he had planted in his garden has “begun to sprout”; in his twelfth, he provides a entirely factual account of an encounter with a merchant; in his fifteenth, he rants in a prophetic tone reminiscent of another character, the Hellfire Preacher, which seems to counter his usual colloquialness. Importantly, there is clear textual evidence linking these three passages to the same speaker: two begin with the epithet “Unreal City”, while the other ends with an evocation of the same place: “Jerusalem Athens Alexandria / Vienna London / Unreal”. This makes it unlikely that they are truly different characters, despite the stylistic differences.'

question_german: In Abbildung 4 wird die Leistung des CNN in Bezug auf die F-Measure mit zunehmender Anzahl von Nachbarn verglichen. Warum wurde laut Text eine maximale Anzahl von 18 Nachbarn gewählt, obwohl eine größere Anzahl von Nachbarn zu einer höheren Performance führen könnte?
question_english: Figure 4 compares the performance of the CNN, as measured by the F-Measure, with an increasing number of neighbors. According to the text, why was a maximum number of 18 neighbors chosen, even though a larger number of neighbors could lead to better performance?
corrected_answer_german: Im Text heißt es, dass eine Erhöhung der Anzahl der Nachbarn über 18 hinaus trotz zunehmender Komplexität keine wesentliche Verbesserung der Leistung brachte. Daher wurden 18 Nachbarn gewählt, um ein Gleichgewicht zwischen Leistung und Rechenaufwand zu finden.
corrected_answer_english: The text states that increasing the number of neighbors beyond 18 offered little improvement in performance despite increasing the complexity. Therefore, 18 neighbors were chosen to balance performance and computational cost.
context: Le nombre de fenêtres voisines considérées s’est avéré être l’un des paramètres les plus importants : les changements de phones se repèrent notamment grâce au contexte. Le MLP supporte moins bien l’augmentation du nombre de données (allant avec l’augmentation du nombre de voisins) que le CNN, dont les couches de convolution effectuent visiblement un premier traitement pertinent et réducteur. La figure 4 illustre l’importance de la taille du contexte pour la tâche de segmentation : les résultats s’améliorent de manière visible avec l’augmentation du nombre de voisins. Nous avons choisi 18 voisins (84 ms), l’augmentation au-delà étant très faible par rapport à l’augmentation de la complexité.

context: 'Comme pour la durée, des différences significatives de la vitesse moyenne entre les deux phases ont été observées (Table 2, Figure 4) avec une ouverture plus rapide que la fermeture (Figure 3), sauf pour les cycles mandibulaires correspondant à la réalisation de /bat/ (p = .21) et de /pat/ (p = .99). La vitesse moyenne d’ouverture est généralement stable, sauf pour les attaques bilabiales sourdes (/pap/, /pat/) pour lesquelles le geste d’ouverture est mesuré moins rapide que dans le cas des attaques /b d s t z/ (Figure 3). question_german: Basierend auf dem Text, welcher Modelltyp, LSTM oder GRU, zeigt im Allgemeinen eine schnellere Konvergenz während des Trainings?
question_english: According to the text, which model type, LSTM or GRU, generally exhibits faster convergence during training?
corrected_answer_german: Im Text heißt es, dass das GRU-Modell typischerweise schneller konvergiert als das LSTM-Modell.
corrected_answer_english: The text states that the GRU model typically converges faster than the LSTM model.
context:
In these configurations, the model was often still improving even after 100 epochs.

Adding the RUSS to the LSTM improves its accuracy both for short prefixes and for positions close to the end of the string. However it sometimes worsens slightly its accuracy for positions 14 to 15. The GRU and RUSS combined model displays great variability from run to run, ranging from perfect accuracy to not much better than the single GRU.

From these results, we note the following salient points:

1. The single LSTM exhibits the unusual feature of better accuracy for the longest distances than for mid-range ones. Our interpretation is that the LSTM learned to specially match the outermost parentheses. How is that possible? First, remember that the LSTM can develop a counting mechanism (section 4), which can thus predict when the closing parenthesis corresponding to the outermost opening parenthesis is expected. Assuming that such a mechanism is available, it suffices to combine it is with another mechanism to remember the first character of the input to correctly predict the last closing parenthesis.

2. Layering two RNNs of the same kind tended to yield small improvements and reinforce the general trends exhibited by their single-layer counterparts.

3. Increasing 4-fold the number of units tended to yield small improvements, and smooth out the general trends exhibited by their single-layer counterparts.
;
4. The behavior of a heterogeneously layered RNN seems to be primarily following the behavior of its first layer. However, the RUSS can have a significant beneficial impact on the behavior of the compound, when employed as a second layer.

question_german: Stimmt der visuelle Trend für 'Valenz' über die Sprachen hinweg im Diagramm mit den Ergebnissen der Silberevaluation hinsichtlich der Sprachen mit Korrelationen über 0,7 überein? Begründen Sie Ihre Antwort.
question_english: Does the visual trend for 'Valence' across languages in the chart align with the findings of the silver evaluation regarding languages with correlations above 0.7? Explain your answer.
corrected_answer_german: Ja, die 'Valenz'-Linie zeigt im Allgemeinen einen Abwärtstrend, wenn wir uns nach rechts auf dem Diagramm zubewegen, was auf niedrigere Korrelationen für Sprachen weiter unten in der Liste hinweist. Dies stimmt mit dem Ergebnis der Silberevaluation überein, dass eine starke Korrelation (r > 0,7) für 'Valenz' für 56 Sprachen erreicht wurde, was darauf hindeutet, dass die übrigen Sprachen wahrscheinlich Korrelationen unterhalb dieses Schwellenwerts aufweisen.
corrected_answer_english: Yes, the 'Valence' line generally shows a downward trend as we move towards the right of the chart, indicating lower correlations for languages further down the list. This aligns with the silver evaluation finding that a strong correlation (r > 0.7) for 'Valence' was achieved for 56 languages, implying the remaining languages likely have correlations below this threshold.
context:
In particular, for our silver evaluation, we intersect TargetMT-test with TargetPred-test and compute the correlation of these two sets individually for each emotion variable. Pearson’s r will be used as correlation measure throughout this paper. Establishing a test set at the very start of our workflow, Source-test, assures that there is a relatively large overlap between the two sets and, by extension, that our requirements for the evaluation are met. The gold evaluation is a somewhat more challenging case, because we can, in general, not guarantee that the overlap of a TargetGold lexicon with TargetPred-test will be of any particular size. For this reason, the words of the embedding model are added to TargetPred-test (see above), maximizing the expected overlap with TargetGold. In practical terms, we intersect TargetGold with TargetPred-test and compute the variable-wise correlation between these sets, in parallel to the silver evaluation. A complementary strategy for maximizing overlap, by exploiting dependencies between published lexicons, is described below.

**Silver Evaluation.** Figure 2 displays the results of our silver evaluation. Languages (x-axis) are sorted by their average performance over all variables (not shown in the plot; tabular data given in the Appendix). As can be seen, the evaluation results for English are markedly better than for any other language. This is not surprising since no (potentially error-prone) machine translation was performed. Apart from that, performance remains relatively stable across most of the languages and starts degrading more quickly only for the last third of them. In particular, for Valence—typically the easiest variable to predict—we achieve a strong performance of r > .7 for 56 languages. On the other hand, for Arousal—typically, the most difficult one to predict—we achieve a solid performance of r > .5 for 55 languages. Dominance and the discrete emotion variables show performance trajectories swinging between these two extremes. We assume that the main factors for explaining performance differences between languages are the quality of the translation and embedding models which, in turn, both depend on the amount of available text data (parallel or monolingual, respectively). Comparing MTLFFN and ridge baseline, we find that the neural network reliably outperforms the linear model. On average over all languages and variables, the MTL models achieve 6.7%-points higher Pearson correlation. Conversely, ridge regression outperforms MTLFFN in only 15 of the total 728 cases (91 languages × 8 variables).'

context:
Figure 4: The effect of encoder layers’ number.

as comparison experiments on the 4-way classification. Figure 4 shows that the F1 scores are increasing until three encoder layers. And when the size of the encoder layer is four or five, the performance of our model is decreasing obviously. With the increasing of the number of encoder layers, the model could capture the richer semantic information. However, the results imply that with the more encoder layers considered, the model could incur the over-fitting problem due to adding more parameters. Therefore, we adopt three encoder layers to encode the arguments as our Baseline in section 3.3.

question_german: 'In der Bildunterschrift wird erwähnt, dass die Experimente in Abbildung 1(b) in der 'Inferenzphase' durchgeführt wurden. Was ist im Kontext von neuronalen maschinellen Übersetzungsmodellen mit ''Inferenzphase'' gemeint und wie unterscheidet sie sich von der Trainingsphase?'
question_english: 'The caption mentions that the experiments in Figure 1(b) were conducted in the ''inference stage.'' In the context of Neural Machine Translation models, what is meant by ''inference stage,'' and how does it differ from the training stage?'
corrected_answer_german: Die 'Inferenzphase' ist der Zeitpunkt, an dem ein trainiertes NMT-Modell verwendet wird, um neue, ungesehene Texte zu übersetzen. Dies unterscheidet sich von der 'Trainingsphase', in der das Modell lernt, aus einem Datensatz zu übersetzen. Während der Inferenz sind die Parameter des Modells festgelegt und es generiert Übersetzungen ausschließlich basierend auf der Eingabe.
corrected_answer_english: The 'inference stage' is when a trained NMT model is used to translate new, unseen text. This differs from the 'training stage' where the model learns to translate from a dataset. During inference, the model's parameters are fixed, and it generates translations based solely on the input.

question_german: Basierend auf den Ergebnissen von Abbildung 4:  Unterstützen die Verteilungen der Funktionsvorkommnisse die Idee, dass Modelle dazu neigen, eine große Anzahl von seltenen Merkmalen zu nutzen, insbesondere bei Verwendung einer L1-Regularisierung?
question_english: Based on the findings in Figure 4: Do the distributions of feature occurrences support the notion that models tend to utilize a large proportion of infrequent features, especially when using L1 regularization?
corrected_answer_german: Nein, die Verteilung der Funktionsvorkommnisse in Abbildung 4 unterstützt nicht die Annahme, dass Modelle dazu neigen, eine große Anzahl von seltenen Merkmalen zu verwenden. Tatsächlich zeigen die Modelle, insbesondere das L1-Modell, einen deutlichen Rückgang der Nutzung bei den am wenigsten häufigen Merkmalen (Vorkommenshäufigkeit von 1). Obwohl sie insgesamt eine große Anzahl von Merkmalen verwenden, ähnelt das Verteilungsmuster stark der Gesamtverteilung der Merkmale, was auf eine ausgewogene Nutzung über verschiedene Vorkommenshäufigkeiten hindeutet.
corrected_answer_english: No, the distribution of feature occurrences in Figure 4 does not support that models heavily utilize infrequent features. In fact, the models, particularly the L1 model, show a significant drop in usage for the least frequent features (occurrence count of 1). While they utilize a large number of features overall, the distribution pattern closely resembles the overall feature distribution, suggesting a balanced usage across different occurrence frequencies.

context: Pour le locuteur 1, l’enregistrement s’est effectué dans la chambre sourde du Laboratoire de Phonétique et Phonologie (CNRS/Sorbonne Nouvelle) à Paris, à l’aide d’un micro-casque hypercardioïde (AKG C520), une carte son Edirol UA25 et le logiciel Sound Studio, v. 3.6.0.0. question_german: In Abbildung 3 wird der Phone Focus für verschiedene Akzente verglichen. In einem früheren Absatz wird eine Metrik erwähnt, die die Genauigkeit der Ausrichtung von Attributionen auf Phoneme misst. Nennen Sie diese Metrik und beschreiben Sie kurz, was sie misst.
question_english: Figure 3 compares the phone focus across different accents. An earlier paragraph mentions a metric used to measure the alignment accuracy of attributions to phonemes. Name this metric and briefly describe what it measures.
corrected_answer_german: Die Metrik heißt Earth Mover's Distance (EMD). Sie quantifiziert den Unterschied zwischen zwei Verteilungen, in diesem Fall eine aus den Attributionen abgeleitete und die andere aus der phonetischen Referenzausrichtung. Ein größerer EMD-Wert weist auf eine schlechtere Ausrichtung hin.
corrected_answer_english: The metric is Earth Mover's Distance (EMD). It quantifies the difference between two distributions, one derived from the attributions and the other from the reference phonetic alignment. A larger EMD value indicates poorer alignment.
context: 'Given a correctly predicted word, we define the distribution p as the uniform distribution over the frames that are aligned with the word, and q as the distribution obtained by normalizing the word-level attribution of the word in the utterance. For each accent, we sample a set of words that were correctly predicted (equally many for all accents) and compute the average of the EMD between the distributions p and q corresponding to each word. This average serves as an alignment accuracy measure for the accent. For the EMD analysis, we restrict ourselves to a set of 380 sentences that have corresponding speech utterances in all accents. This way, the content is mostly identical across all accents. Table 2 shows the averaged EMD values for each accent computed across all correctly predicted words. Larger EMD values signify poorer alignments. The overall values clearly show that the alignments from US and Canadian-accented samples are most accurate and the alignments from the Indian-accented samples are most inaccurate.'

context:
'The best results for this sub-task were also achieved only by applying preprocessing steps to an LSTM model. Most likely, the problem was that our external dataset largely aimed to recognize names of top twitter accounts, which most frequently occur as usernames in tweets. However, in our case they were anonymized in both training and test sets (@USER). Last table shows the scores of our submissions for sub-task C:


Table 3: Results for Sub-task C.

For the last sub-task, which was devoted to categorizing targets of offense, a considerable increase in F1-score can be observed by using the external datasets for postprocessing. Hence, the results showed that using a lexical lookup could be much more efficient in categorizing the possible victims than in identifying the presence of aggression per se. Below one can also find the confusion matrices of our best runs:

**System** **(Sumbis-** **F1 (macro)** **Accuracy** **sion)**

All TIN baseline 0.4702 0.8875

All UNT baseline 0.1011 0.1125

**LSTM + Prepr.** **0.5246** **0.8417**

LSTM + Prepr. + 0.5022 0.8833 Lex. lookup

Table 2: Results for Sub-task B.'

question_german: Wie hoch ist die Genauigkeit (in Prozent) des CNN-Glove-Modells für Sub-Task A, wenn die Anzahl der falsch positiven Vorhersagen von 'OFF' um 50 % reduziert würde?

corrected_answer_german: Die aktuelle Genauigkeit beträgt (584 + 140) / (584 + 36 + 100 + 140) = 724 / 860 = 84,19 %. Dies erhöht die Anzahl der korrekten Vorhersagen auf 774 (ursprünglich 724). Die neue Genauigkeit beträgt 774 / 860 = 89,99 %, also ungefähr 90 %.
corrected_answer_english: The current accuracy is (584 + 140) / (584 + 36 + 100 + 140) = 724 / 860 = 84.19%. Reducing false positives of 'OFF' by 50% means 50 fewer instances would be misclassified. This increases the number of correct predictions to 774 (originally 724). The new accuracy is 774 / 860 = 89.99%, approximately 90%.

Dies liegt daran, dass es im Allgemeinen als schlimmer angesehen wird, die Verbreitung schädlicher Inhalte unkontrolliert zuzulassen, als nicht-beleidigende Inhalte fälschlicherweise zu kennzeichnen.
corrected_answer_english: The text suggests that false negatives (missing actual offensive content) are potentially more serious for the task of identifying offensive language. This is because allowing harmful content to propagate unchecked is generally considered worse than mistakenly flagging non-offensive content.
context:
Our ensemble model performed better than the individual models and was also submitted to the competition, which was finally ranked 5th amongst 103 participants. Figure 3 presents the confusion matrix of our submission for Sub-task A. Some of the samples from the training dataset, which were very hard for our final model to predict are:

More like #Putin every day. #MAGA URL

_•_ (OFF)

@USER Hitler would be so proud of David

_•_ Hogg trying to disarm American citizen so when Democrats come to power-we are helpless And cannot defend ourselves-; that’s why we have they AR15’s (NOT)

@USER good job (sarcasm). Also great they

_•_ have gun control laws its saving lives! (More sarcasm). (OFF)

context: Sub-Task C is 3-way classification, with 2 minority classes. Again, we run all our classifiers with unigram and bigram combinations across all sampling methods (including no sampling) on this imbalanced dataset. In addition, we use 4 different configurations to generate samples for each of the two minority classes to obtain 4 balanced datasets. C1 is created with random oversampling of the two minority classes; C2 is created with synthetic oversampling of the two minority classes; C3 is created with random oversampling of minority class group (GRP) and synthetic oversampling of minority class other (OTH); and C4 is random oversampling of minority class OTH and synthetic oversampling of minority class GRP.

question_german: Im Vergleich zum im Artikel genannten F1-Macro-Score von 0,8136, wie verändert sich die Interpretation der Leistung des Klassifikators, wenn man die Konfusionsmatrix betrachtet?
question_english: In relation to the reported F1-macro score of 0.8136 in the paper, how does looking at the confusion matrix change your interpretation of the classifier's performance?
corrected_answer_german: Während der F1-Macro-Score von 0,8136 auf eine gute Gesamtleistung hindeutet, zeigt die Konfusionsmatrix, dass der Klassifikator eine Tendenz zur Klassifizierung von Tweets als 'NOT' aufweist. Obwohl der Klassifikator 'NOT'-Tweets gut identifizieren kann (hohe True-Negative-Rate), klassifiziert er 'OFF'-Tweets häufig falsch als 'NOT' (hohe False-Negative-Rate), was auf ein potenzielles Problem bei der korrekten Identifizierung von beleidigenden Inhalten hindeutet. Dies unterstreicht die Bedeutung der Untersuchung der Fehlerverteilung, da ein guter Makro-Durchschnittsscore eine schlechte Leistung bei einer bestimmten Klasse verschleiern kann.
corrected_answer_english: While the F1-macro score of 0.8136 suggests good overall performance, the confusion matrix reveals a bias towards classifying tweets as 'NOT.'  Although the classifier is good at identifying 'NOT' tweets (high true negative rate), it frequently misclassifies 'OFF' tweets as 'NOT' (high false negative rate), indicating a potential problem with correctly identifying offensive content. This highlights the importance of examining the distribution of errors as a good macro-average score may mask poor performance on a specific class.

corrected_answer_german: Pronomenreferenz: „Sie kam spät an. Ihr Zug hatte Verspätung.“ „Ihr“ stellt eine Verbindung zum vorherigen Satz her, ohne „Sie“ oder „ankam“ zu wiederholen.
corrected_answer_english: Pronoun reference: 'She arrived late.  Her train was delayed.'  'Her' connects to the previous sentence without repeating 'She' or 'arrived'.
context: 'Although these may present at first glance as problematic low cohesion, on closer inspection, they are actually false alarms—or at least, examples of when lexical cohesion alone cannot always tell the whole cohesion story. Almost all are quite short sentences: for example, sentence 27 reads ‘It must not be accepted or excused’. Shorter sentences obviously provide fewer opportunities for content words to occur, which in turn provides fewer opportunities for lexical repetition—though other forms of cohesion may be present, such as the co-reference occurring in sentence 27 with the word ‘it’.'

corrected_answer_german: Der Auszug erwähnt, dass die Kategorien 'allgemein' und 'geplant' die schlechteste Leistung aufweisen. Insbesondere 'positive Regulierung' (PREG), 'negative Regulierung' (NREG) und 'Regulierung'(REG)  innerhalb dieser Kategorien tragen zu einer hohen Anzahl von falsch positiven und falsch negativen Ergebnissen bei.
corrected_answer_english: The excerpt mentions that the categories 'general' and 'planned' show the worst performance. In particular, 'positive regulation' (PREG), 'negative regulation' (NREG), and 'regulation' (REG) within these categories contribute to a high number of false positive and false negative results.
context: 'We can also infer from the confusion matrix shown in Figure 3 that positive regulation, _negative regulation and regulation among general_ category and planned category triggers are causing many false positives and false negatives thus degrading the model’s performance.'

question_german: Was ist der Unterschied zwischen einer Bewertung mit Punktzahl 3 und einer Bewertung mit Punktzahl 5?
question_english: What is the difference between a score of 3 and a score of 5?
corrected_answer_german: Ein Wert von 3 bedeutet, dass die vorhergesagte Entität korrekt, aber unvollständig ist, wohingegen ein Wert von 5 bedeutet, dass die vorhergesagte Entität vollständiger als die annotierte Entität ist und vom Experten akzeptiert wird.
corrected_answer_english: A score of 3 indicates the predicted entity is correct but could be more complete, whereas a score of 5 means the predicted entity is more complete than the annotated entity and is accepted by the expert.
context: '**SCORE = 3:** The predicted entity is correct but could be more complete. The prediction is accepted by the expert. The entity normal HaCaT _lines is annotated as anatomical structure in the_ test set but the NER extracts only HaCaT lines with the same label. **SCORE = 4:** The predicted entity is equally correct and is accepted by the expert. As an example the annotated entity in test set is 196b-5p, as an anatomical structure but the NER extracts _-196b-5p, as an entity with the same tag._ **SCORE = 5:** The predicted entity is more complete than the annotated entity and is accepted by the expert. The annotated entity in the test set is _drugs with the tag chemical and the NER extracts_ _Alzheimer’s drugs with the same tag._'

question_german: Basierend auf dem Text, warum könnten vereinfachte Texte einen höheren Anteil an definiten NPs und Possessivpronomen aufweisen?
question_english: Based on the text, why might simplified texts have a higher proportion of definite NPs and possessive determiners?
corrected_answer_german: Vereinfachte Texte zielen auf Klarheit und einfaches Verstehen ab, insbesondere für Menschen mit Legasthenie. Sie neigen dazu, potenziell mehrdeutige Pronomen durch explizitere Nominalphrasen und Possessivpronomen zu ersetzen. Dies macht den Text leichter verständlich.
corrected_answer_english: Simplified texts aim for clarity and ease of understanding, especially for those with dyslexia.  They tend to replace potentially ambiguous pronouns with more explicit definite noun phrases and possessive determiners. This makes the text easier to follow.
context: 'The composition of the chains varies with the complexity of the texts as shown in Figure 1. The percentage of personal pronouns included in coreference chains is larger in the original text (36.5%), rather than in simplified texts (19.4%). The simplified texts present significantly more definite nouns and possessive determiners (respectively, 36.0% in the simplified texts, and 18.7% in the original texts). Indeed, the pronouns have been deleted or replaced by their referent. In original texts, possessive determiners (12.9% vs 10.1 % in simple texts) or relative pronouns are frequent, while the percent of proper names is more important than in simpler texts. This observation is in line with studies in cognitive psychology and neuroscience, such as Li et al. (2018), Jaffe et al. (2018), McMillan et al. (2012) and Heine et al. (2006), showing that the pronouns require more reasoning to find its antecedent. If the definite noun phrases is frequent, the reference chains in original texts contains synonyms or hypernyms, while in simpler texts, it contains several repetitions of the same referent.'

question_german: Der Text erwähnt, dass die Lexikographen bei der Erstellung des Datensatzes die Methode 'Pflücke die niedrig hängenden Früchte' anwendeten. Wie könnte diese Methode zu dem hohen Prozentsatz an 'strong equivalence' beigetragen haben?

corrected_answer_german: Indem sie die einfachsten Verknüpfungen priorisierten, bei denen es sich wahrscheinlich um die offensichtlichsten Fälle von 'starker Äquivalenz' handelt, erstellten die Lexikographen auf natürliche Weise einen Datensatz, der in Richtung dieser Kategorie verzerrt ist. Diese Methode spiegelt nicht unbedingt die tatsächliche Verteilung der Äquivalenztypen wider, sondern eher eine Verzerrung hin zu leicht identifizierbaren Verknüpfungen.
corrected_answer_english: By prioritizing the easiest links, which are likely the most obvious 'strong equivalence' cases, the lexicographers naturally built a dataset skewed towards this category. This method doesn't necessarily reflect the actual distribution of equivalence types but rather a bias towards easily identifiable links.
context: 'Later, when working on the extension of the data set, lexicographers assumed ’pick the low hanging fruit’ method while analysing and linking pairs that seemed likely to be good equivalents at the very first glance.'

question_german: Basierend auf dem Text des Artikels, welche Heuristik trug die meisten Paare bei, die zur Erstellung des automatisch erweiterten Datensatzes verwendet wurden, und wie wurde diese Heuristik eingesetzt?
question_english: According to the paper's text, which heuristic contributed the most pairs used to create the automatically enhanced dataset, and how was this heuristic applied?
corrected_answer_german: Die Heuristik, die die meisten Paare beisteuerte, überprüfte, ob die Lemmata der polnischen und englischen lexikalischen Einheiten ihre einzige Übersetzung in einem zweisprachigen Wörterbuch sind.
corrected_answer_english: The heuristic that contributed the most pairs checked if the lemmas of the Polish and English lexical units are its only translation in a bilingual dictionary.
context: 'From our initial set of Polish-English lexical units, we extracted such pairs in which the lemma of the English unit was the only translation given by the dictionary. The obtained subset amounted to 8057 pairs. The last idea was to use ’femininity’ relation from plWordNet which links feminine gender nouns to their masculine derivational bases. ... The set of pairs generated in result of applying all heuristics amounted to 13 298 pairs of Polish-English lexical units. ... The heuristics that contributed the larger number of pairs checked if the lemmas of the Polish and English lexical units are its only translation in a bilingual dictionary.'

corrected_answer_german: Im Text heißt es, dass Europa fast 800 Milliarden Dollar in die digitale Infrastruktur investieren muss, unter anderem um den Bedarf an HPC-Leistung zu decken, was auf einen Mangel an Angebot im Vergleich zum Verbrauch hindeutet.
corrected_answer_english: The text states that Europe needs to invest close to $800 billion in digital infrastructure, partly to address the demand for HPC power, indicating a shortage in supply compared to its consumption needs.
category: Questions Requiring Additional Context from the research paper
context: According to estimations by the European Commission, Europe needs to invest close to $800bn in its digital infrastructure to catch up with the United States and China.[26] Although this is a total estimation that includes investments in fiber-optics networks, 5G networks and other ICT infrastructure, a substantial part of these investments are needed to meet European demand for high performance computing (HPC) power. Europe is lagging behind other global economic powers in providing computing power for computing intensive applications. Although Europe consumes 29% of global HPC resources it supplies less than 5% of them (Figure 7).[27]

question_german: Welche zwei Dateiformate haben die gleiche Anzahl an Dateien und werden im Text als essentiell für Tools zur automatischen Spracherkennung beschrieben?

corrected_answer_german: mp3 und wav
corrected_answer_english: mp3 and wav
context: Media files dominate, and ELAN files (.eaf) make up the most substantial portion of transcription file types (see Figure 1) . The variety of formats presents a challenge when designing language technologies which rely on importing files created or processed by other tools. Standards have emerged to improve the interoperability of language tools. In recent years, there have been proposals to standardise formats such as XIGT (Goodman et al., 2015) for Interlinear Glossed Text; and to extend XML processing tools such as XPATH (Bird et al., 2006). Framework specifications such as EXMARaLDA span working with individual transcriptions through to corpus management (Schmidt and W¨orner, 2009). Wider adoption of tools such as SayMore[4], and proposals like Holton and Thieberger’s collections management tool, recently released as Digame[5] would make ingesting material into archives a more reliable and quicker process, and improve downstream processes such as ASR which rely on access to language corpora. Corpus conversion tools such as Salt and Pepper map between different language data formats using graph data structures (Druskat et al., 2016).

question_german: Abbildung 2 legt nahe, dass es innerhalb jeder Gedichtgruppe keine positive Korrelation zwischen dem Veröffentlichungsjahr und der Konkretheit gibt. Welche zusätzliche Information aus dem Text unterstützt diese Aussage weiter?
question_english: Figure 2 suggests that there is no positive correlation between publication year and concreteness within each group of poems. What additional information from the text further supports this statement?
corrected_answer_german: Der Text gibt an, dass eine statistische Analyse mithilfe eines linearen Regressionsmodells keine signifikante Korrelation zwischen dem Veröffentlichungsjahr und der Konkretheit sowohl für Gedichte vor 1912 als auch nach 1912 ergab.
corrected_answer_english: The text states that a statistical analysis using a linear regression model confirmed no significant correlation between publication year and concreteness within both pre-1912 and post-1912 poems.
context: We first tested whether the concreteness of a poem is correlated with the poem’s publication year and found a significant correlation of r = 0.25 (p < 0.001) among the 188 19th century and contemporary poems (not including Imagist poems). This suggests that, overall, poems published later in time contain words with higher concreteness. We then tested whether this correlation is consistent across time, or if there is a significant shift prior to and after the Imagist movement. To do so, we constructed a linear regression model with two predictors: a continuous variable for the publication year, and a binary variable indicating whether the poem was published before the Imagism movement began in 1912. We found that while the binary factor is a significant predictor of concreteness (t = −3.43, p < 0.001), publication year does not capture a significant amount of the residual variance (t = −0.38, p = 0.70). Among poems published before 1912, there is no significant correlation between concreteness and publication year (r = −0.22, p = 0.15); among poems published after 1912, there is also no significant correlation between concreteness and publication year (r = 0.016, p = 0.85).

context: Although in comparison, the evaluation scores of our best model XLM15 hyp+src/hyp+ref are set more linearly than the baseline BERT regressor, the scores of all models seem much dispersed in the low DA area (DA < 0.0). This indicates that all evaluation models listed here tend to miss-evaluate when a hypothesis is poor. Furthermore, we show Pearson’s correlation score for each of high and low DA score range in Table 5. As we confirmed in the scatter figures, the correlation scores of low DA is low; evaluation models work poorly when hypotheses are poor. However, the reduction rate of Pearson’s scores from high DA to low DA is small with XLM15 hyp+src/hyp+ref and hyp+src. Therefore adding source sentences has an impact to stabilize the evaluation performance when hypotheses are low-quality.

question_german: Basierend auf den in Abbildung 4 beschriebenen Ergebnissen, wie stark sinkt die Leistung des vorgeschlagenen Modells (in Prozentpunkten F1-Score) bei einem Trainingsdatensatz von 40 % im Vergleich zu seiner Leistung bei Verwendung von 100 % der Trainingsdaten?
question_english: Based on the results described in Figure 4, on a 40% training data set, how much does the performance of the proposed model drop (in F1 Score percentage points), compared to its performance when using 100% of the training data?
context: 'This section investigates the proposed model on data scarcity. On ATIS, the percentage of training samples are reduced down to 20% of the original size, with a reduction size of 20%. This setting is challenging and few previous works have experimented. Results in Figure 3 show that the proposed model consistently outperforms other models, especially in low-resource conditions. Furthermore, reductions of performance from the proposed model are much smaller, in comparison to other models. For instance, at percentage 40%, the proposed model only lose 1.17% of its best F1 score whereas GCDT loses 3.62% of its F1 score. This suggests that the proposed model is more robust to low resource than other models.'
